questions.text: Which of the following is quantitative assessment of metabolic changes in solid tumors?
questions.solution: B) WHO, RECIST 1.0, RECIST 1.1 are anatomical response criteria and PERCIST is metabolic response criteria. To avoid continuing anti-cancer treatment with no efficacy, the accurate assessment of therapeutic response is essential. The Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) version 1.1 is the most commonly used criteria to assess tumor response. The RECIST criteria use the uni-dimensional measurement instead of the bi-dimensional criterion in the WHO guidelines. RECIST 1.1 FDG PET was added as a complimentary assessment PET Response Criteria in Solid Tumors PERCIST (1.0) Many new drugs are cytostatic Tumor response associated with decrease in metabolism No reduction in size

questions.text: Iodine isotope not for scanning
questions.solution: B) I127 is stable isotope iodine isotopes used in radiology are: • I – 123 : half life 13 hrs used for functional scan • I – 124 is used for PET scan • I – 125: half life is 60 days, used for radioiodine assay, brachytherapy • I – 127 is stable isotope • I – 131: half life is 8 days , used to treat well differentiated thyroid cancer

questions.text: Prophylactic craniospinal irradiation
questions.solution: b) Small cell has high chances of cerebral micro metastasis

questions.text: Which of the following is not a commonly used window in CT Scan?
questions.solution: Chest window a. Lung window used to look for lung parenchymal pathologies b. soft tissue or mediastinal window is used to look for mediastinal pathologies c. blood vessel window is used to look for great vessels and its branches in thorax

questions.text: Most radiosensitive structure in eye
questions.solution: a) lens Lens is radiosensitive, conjuctiva and cornea are moderately radiosensitive, optic nerve & retina are radioresistant

questions.text: Isotope not used in PET scan
questions.solution: B) Thallium 201 • Tc RBC is used for ventricular function assessment. It is known as gated MUGA scan. • Tc pyrophosphate is used for the myocardial infarct scintigrahy. This isotope binds to the infarct and the isotope appears hot on the scan

questions.text: Which do not cause calcification in liver?
questions.solution: b) Actually all can cause calcification but infection and benign tumours are most likely causes. Causes of calcification Infections Tuberculosis, histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis, brucellosis Echinococcal cyst Schistosomiasis, cysticercosis, filariasis, paragonimiasis, armillifer, guinea worm Cytomegalovirus, toxoplasma, Pneumocystis carinii Chronic granulomatous disease of childhood Chronic amebic and pyogenic abscess Vascular Hepatic artery aneurysm Portal vein thrombosis Hematoma Benign tumor Hemangioma Hepatocellular adenoma Infantile hemangioendothelioma Regenerating nodule (capsule) Cyst Primary malignant tumor Fibrolamellar carcinoma Hepatocellular carcinoma Choloangiocarcinoma Epithelioid hemangioendothelioma Hepatoblastoma Metastatic tumor Mucinous carcinoma of colon, breast, stomach, ovary Others: melanoma, thyroid, osteosarcoma, malignant teratoma, chondrosarcoma, carcinoid, leiomyosarcoma, neuroblastoma Biliary Calculus Ascariasis, chlonorchis

questions.text: After child treated for meduloblastoma planned for radiotherapy for spinal metastasis preferred therapy is-
questions.solution: d) Proton therapy or IMRT is recommended in RT for Medulloblastoma

questions.text: Patient with h/O tachyrrhythmias is on implantable cardioverter defibrillator.He develops shock. Best method to know the position and integrity of ICD is to do
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Explanation :Plain radiograph is indicated here to see the physical integrity and position of ICD.

questions.text: Best noninvasive investigation to check for viability of myocardium is
questions.solution: Ans.:B Ref. FDG PET is the IOC for myocardial viability. However, if they ask myocardial scar then CEMR is required. Scar shows delayed enhancement.

questions.text: Expansion of the contrast filled space in myelography is seen in
questions.solution: Ans.:B Ref.: Grainger radiology Enhancement of the contrast filled space on myelography implies Intra duralextramedullarytumour which is expanding the CSF space.

questions.text: The following chest x-ray was recorded from a patient presenting to emergency with breathlessness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B Hydropneumothorax Note the air lucency and air-fluid level in the left pleural space. Ref: Sutton: radiology 7/e p 92

questions.text: 193 A 20 year- old male patients presents with a lesion in the knee. The X- ray appearance is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans A. Osteoclastoma Note the subarticular location , with soap bubble like appearance and expansile/eccentric nature. Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e p 202

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution: Ans. a. Spondylolisthesis Normal appearance of lateral oblique view is Scotty dog But remember, beheaded scotty dog is spondylolisthesis and scotty dog with collar is spondylolysis. Ref: Apley’s System of Orthopedics and Fractures 9/e p 485

questions.text: Patient with carcinoma endometrium treated with pelvic external beamir radiation to whole pelvis. which of the followingorganshereis radiosensitive:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Different tissues tolerate different doses of radiation, but the ovaries are by far the most radiosensitive. They tolerate up to 2500 rads, while the other tissues listed tolerate between 5000 and 20,000 rads. Acute evidence of excessive radiation exposure includes tissue necrosis and inflammation, resulting in enteritis, cystitis, vulvitis, proctosigmoiditis, and possible bone marrow suppression. Chronic effects of excessive radiation exposure are manifest months to years after therapy and include vasculitis, fibrosis, and deficient cellular regrowth; these can result in proctitis, cystitis, fistulas, scarring, and stenosis. The relative resistance of normal tissue (cervix and vagina) in cervical cancer allows high surface doses approaching 15,000 to 20,000 rads to be delivered to the tumor with intracavitary devices, and, because of the inverse square law, significantly lower doses of radiation reach the bladder and rectum.

choices.text: Pericardial collection due to esophageal rupture
Flaial chest due to fracture of 5,6,7, 8th ribs.

questions.text: A 12-year-old male involved in a bike accident presents to emergency department with cough, dyspnea and chest discomfort. He was found to have a BP of 130/80 mm Hg, pulse rate 86/min, RR 22/min. Pulse oximeter shows a saturation on 98%.A chest X-ray was obtained in the emergency and is shown below. What is the likely pathology?
questions.solution: Ans. C. Pneumothorax with lung collapse CXR shows hyperlucent lung with no identifiable bronchovascular markings along with underlying lung collapse.

questions.text: Non-visualization of gallbladder in hepatic scintigraphy is suggestive of:
questions.solution: Ans. C. Acutecholecystitis due to gallstones HIDA cholescintigraphy in acute cholecystitis will demonstrate non-visualisation of the gallbladder as the cystic duct is obstructed due to GB wall edema in this patient. However, note IOC for acute cholecystitis is USG now.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a finding in the below chest X-ray?
questions.solution: Ans.(b) Pulmonary venous hypertension This is a typical Box shaped heart shown in the image and finding of ebstein anomaly. CXR in this disease shows RA enlargement,oligaemia and a narrow vascular pedicle. Findings on chest radiographs largely depend on the severity of the abnormality and the degree to which the tricuspid valve is displaced downwards There is often severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which may result in an elevated apex. Classically, the heart is described as having a "box shape"on a frontal chest radiograph.

questions.text: Below is radioactive testing scan for thyroid pathology. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis? Tc-99m [pertechnetate] thyroid scan Dose and route of administration 3-5 mCi IV Timing of imaging – 20 minutes after Tc-99m pertechnetate administration Camera: gamma camera Collimator: pinhole Window: 20% energy window centered at 140 KeV
questions.solution: Ans. b) Hypersecreting adenoma Increased uptake noted in the right lobe of thyroid gland along with suppressed in left lobe of thyroid

questions.text: Which gives a negative test on FDG PET?
questions.solution: Ans. C tumors which have less mitotic activity and those who measure < 1 cm in size show decreased uptake on PET and constitute a false negative result. The examples include- -Bronchoalveolar carcinoma -Lung metastasis from mucinous extrapulmonary tumor -Tumor response after chemotherapy -Typical carcinoid

questions.text: DSA angiography image is shown. What is the diagnosis image
questions.solution: Ans. A imaging evaluation is done by CT angiography. Extracranial ICA psuedoaneurysm can be seen by Doppler USG

questions.text: Characteristic of venous blood Flow of lower limb in duplex Doppler is?
questions.solution: Ans. B Venous flow • Intra abdominal pressure changes with respect to respiration due to movement of diaphragm. This leads to change in the venous blood flow in lower limbs. normally biphasic flow pattern in femoral vein is observed. • If the patient holds his breath, venous flow stops • A Valsalva manoeuvre will reverse the flow in the lower extremities • Squeezing the patients calf will augment the venous flow. Arterial flow • Normal arterial flow is triphasic: forward flow in systole, reverse flow in late systole or early diastole, forward flow in late diastole

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis based on the findings in the CT scan given below?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Extra dural haemorrhage: Biconvex appearance of haemorrhage on CT skull suggests extradural haemorrhage. This is due to rupture of middle meningeal artery. Pterion is the anatomical landmark to see the location of middle meningeal artery. • Subdural haemorrhage: concavo convex shaped hematoma , not limited by sutures of skull, hyperdense suggests acute SDH. Chronic SDH is dark dur to reduced density of hematoma over time

questions.text: Which of the following doesn’t use ionizing radiation?
questions.solution: Ans: A CT, Angiography and mammography uses Xrays. MRI and USG do notuse any ionizing radiation

questions.text: Empty thecal sac sign is seen in?
questions.solution: Ans: B Arachnoiditis is inflammation of arachnoid layer. In this condition, the caudal nerve roots attach themselves to dural sac and thecal sac looks empty. This can be visualized on MRI spine.

questions.text: Most probable diagnosis on the below xray is?
questions.solution: Ans:A The given x ray is cervical xray AP view showing cervical rib

questions.text: Name the type of investigation shown in the below image.
questions.solution: Ans: C Myelography is done by injecting dye into spinal cord through lumbar puncture. It was previously used to detect spinal cord pathologies. This investigation is now replaced by MRI.

questions.text: The below logo is used to indicate?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Radiation hazard Trefoil symbol denotes radiation hazard with each leaf of trefoil separated by an angle of 60 degree

questions.text: Most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans: C Air below the diaphragm suggests pneumoperitoneum.

questions.text: ACRTI-RADS scan for thyroid nodule characteristics include all except:
questions.solution: Ans. C ACRTI – RADS stands for American college of radiology – thyroid imaging reporting and data system. It uses USG to characterise thyroid lesions TIRADS includes • Shape • Margin • Echogenicity • Presence of echogenic foci • Composition To know vascularity, Doppler has to be done.

questions.text: Imaging modality employed in PI-RAD reporting scheme for prostate glands is all except:
questions.solution: Ans. A A combination of imaging findings (T2W, DWI, and dynamic contrast enhancement [DCE]) predicts the probability of a cancer that is clinically significant, which is defined as the presence of any of the following 6: • Gleason score ?7 (including 3+4 with prominent but not predominant Gleason 4 component) • volume >0.5 mL • extraprostatic extension Each lesion is assigned a score from 1 to 5 indicating the likelihood of clinically significant cancer: PI-RADS 1: very low (clinically significant cancer is highly unlikely to be present) PI-RADS 2: low (clinically significant cancer is unlikely to be present) PI-RADS 3: intermediate (the presence of clinically significant cancer is equivocal) PI-RADS 4: high (clinically significant cancer is likely to be present) PI-RADS 5: very high (clinically significant cancer is highly likely to be present) PI-RADS X: component of exam technically inadequate or not performed

choices.text: Vertebral fracture due to cervical traction

questions.text: Winking owl sign is seen in:
questions.solution: Ans. B In vertebral bodies, when one of the pedicles is destroyed, it looks like winking owl sign. This condition occurs in vertebral metastasis.. pedicle involvement is more typical to metastasis. Vertebral disc involvement is more pointing towards vertebral tuberculosis or other infective causes.

questions.text: A MRI contrast used for imaging liver is:
questions.solution: Ans. B Hepato biliary specific agent in MRI and LIRADS is Gadoxetate.

questions.text: X-ray spine of a child is shown. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. B Rugger jersey sign is seen in renal osteodystrophy.

questions.text: A 2-years-old child with lump in abdomen, abdominal pain, USG-Hydronephrotic Right kidney with thin cortical parenchyma. Best imaging method to assess functional status of kidney:
questions.solution: Ans. C To know the function of kidney, isotope scans need to be done. DTPA or DMSA scan can be done to know the fuction of kidney

questions.text: Half-life of radioactive fluorine 18:
questions.solution: Ans. A Factual question

questions.text: Iodine isotope used for radio ablation of thyroid in Graves’ disease is:
questions.solution: Ans. C I-131 is used to destroy thyroid tissue as it is a strong ? emitter and a strong ? emitter. It is used in radio abalation of thyroid in graves disease and thryroid Ca metastasis.

questions.text: Mushroom cap sign in MRI is seen in:
questions.solution: Ans. D Mushroom cap sign is seen in deep recto sigmoid endometriosis. It is seen on T2 weighted MRI.

questions.text: Investigation not useful in myeloma:
questions.solution: Ans. B Multiple myeloma is cold on a bone scn. Hence bone scan is not useful in this condition

questions.text: MUGA scan not useful in:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Technitium RBC labelled MUGA scan is used to assess ventricular functions like ejection fraction, wall motion and stroke volume. It is not used to assess perfusion of the myocardium. For myocardial perfusion we use thallium scan, Tc-sestamibitc

questions.text: Sunburst pattern in skull is seen in all of the following except
questions.solution: Ans: B • Sunray or sunburst appearance is due to ossification along sharpey’sfibres and periosteal reaction. This is classically seen in osteosarcoma. Conditions such as neuroblastoma metastasis, hemangioma which have vascular proliferation are also known to produce sunburst pattern. • Appearance of pagets disease in skull is known as cotton wool skull or osteoporosis circumscripta and classical tam-o-schanter skull.

questions.text: Which of the following radiological features are not seen in osteogenes is imperfect
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) • Saber shin is seen in congenital syphilis • Wormian bones are seen in osteogenesis imperfect, hypothyroidism ,pyknodysostosis, cleidocranial dysplasia etc • Osteogenesis imperfect has osteoporosis like features with thinned out cortex. • Coxa vara is a deformity occurring during multiple bone fractures.

choices.text: 150 milliseivert for lens exposure in normal people

questions.text: Which of the following is correct regarding the exposure limits between normal public and radiologists?
questions.solution: Ans: D Normal values of radiation exposure per year are • 1 miliseivert for normal people • 20 miliseivert for radiologists • Lens exposure is not calculated for normal people.

questions.text: Which of the following is stochastic effects of radiation?
questions.solution: Ans: A Two types of radiation effects • Stochastic effects : these effects are directly proportional to the amount of radiation exposure occurred. There is not definitve threshold above which these effects ocuur. Example : mutations and carcinogenesis • Deterministic effects: these are the effects of radiation which occurs after a definitve threshold of radiation exposure. Examples: skin erythema, cataract, fetal abnormality.

questions.text: Which of the following is the radioactive scan used to access phagocytosis
questions.solution: Ans: B Macrophages take up tc- Sulphur colloid which is used to assess the function of phagocytosis

questions.text: Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis on the below echocardiography
questions.solution: Ans: C Enlargement of right atrium is seen in tricuspid atresia among the above given choices.

choices.text: It uses electromagnetic field to accelerate electrons
Electrons cannot be used directly for radiotherapy
4-5 mv X-rays are produced from 4-5 mev electrons
Multileaf collimator uses to focus the beams generated for treatment

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct regarding LINAC
questions.solution: Ans: B • LINAC : linear accelerator which uses electromagnetic waves to accelerate the electrons. These electrons can be directly used for radiotherapy for example in cutaneous t cell lymphomas or they can be used to produce x rays. • IMRT is intensity modulated radiotheraphy which used maultileafcollimater to focus the beams generated for treatment. • A lateral decubitus projection is most sensitive, able to identify even a small amount of fluid. • Ultrasound allows the detection of small amounts of pleural locular fluid, with positive identification of amounts as small as 3-5 mL, that cannot be identified by radiographs

questions.text: What is the score of as per Speltzer Martin criteria, for a patient with a AV malformation in deep thalamic area with a nidus of more than 5 cm.
questions.solution: Ans: B

questions.text: In which of the following conditions Nexus criteria is used
questions.solution: Ans: B NEXUS criteria. NEXUS stands for national emergency X ray utilization study criteria.

questions.text: Nucleus of an atom consists of?
questions.solution: Ans: A & C Ref: NCERT Textbook Explanation: Atoms consist of three basic particles: protons, electrons, and neutrons. The nucleus (center) of the atom contains the protons (positively charged) and the neutrons (no charge). The outermost regions of the atom are called electron shells and contain the electrons (negatively charged).

choices.text: To distinguish mass coming out as solid parenchymal structure from adjacent mass

questions.text: Claw sign is useful in?
questions.solution: Ans 2: C & E Ref: Diagnostic Imaging of Infants and Children/Vol 1 Explanation: The claw sign is useful in determining whether a mass arises from a solid structure or is located adjacent to it and distorts the outline. It refers to the sharp angles on either side of the mass, which the surrounding normal parenchyma forms when the mass has arisen from the parenchyma. As such, normal parenchyma extends some way around the mass.Claw sign is also seen in intussusception, also you may see an occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen, giving the "coiled spring” appearance. Extra edge: Radiological signs in intussusception ? Claw sign ? Meniscus sign ? Empty right iliac fossa ? Pincer sign ? Coiled spring sign ? Target sign

questions.text: Naturally occurring isotopes include?
questions.solution: Ans 3: D & E Ref:Introduction to Radiochemistry by David J Explanation:Radon 222 is major contributor to indoor radiation exposure. Common naturally occurring radioisotopes include • H-3 • Beryllium-10 • Radium-226 • Radon-222 • Na-22 • Krypton-81 • I-129 and I-131 • Sr-90 • Se-82 Cs-137, Ir-192 and Co-60 are produced artificially or as a by-product in a nuclear reactor and do not occur naturally.

questions.text: Which among the following is/are utilised in teletherapy?
questions.solution: Ans: A C D E Ref: Sumer Sethi 6th Ed/177, 184 Explanation:Teletherapy is based on cobalt machine which utilises gamma photons, and LINAc which produces X-rays, photons and electrons. The source of gamma rays is mostly Co-60 or Cs-137.

questions.text: White matter lesions in brain can be visualised by?
questions.solution: Ans : C D E Ref: Pediatric Brain and Spine: An Atlas of MRI and Spectroscopy, Sutton 7th Ed, Fenichel Pediatric Neurology Explanation: Historically, skull-X rays were used to identify subcortical white matter, but their ability to visualise white matter lesions in white matter diseases is so low that they are not even performed or recommended these days as part of work-up in suspected white matter disease. We can see white matter lesions on both CT and MRIalthough the single best investigation is MRI.MR spectroscopy can be useful in white matter diseases like vanishing white matter, where it may show profound decrease in white matter signal and extra signals from lactate and glucose. USG skull is not useful to visualise white matter lesions as well.

questions.text: Dose of radiation exposure in linear accelerator is done by?
questions.solution: Ans : A Ref: Innovations in Radiation Oncology, Sumer Sethi 6th Ed Explanation: The dose of radiation exposure in a linear accelerator is measured by Rad/min, also known as Monitor unit.

questions.text: Persistent posterior urethral valve in neonates is confirmed by?
questions.solution: Ans: A D E Ref: Nelson 20th Ed, Sutton 7th Ed Explanation:The diagnosis of PUV is made by Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU), also called as voiding cystourethrogram (VCUG) that demonstrates the hallmark findings of a dilated and elongated posterior urethra during the voiding phase when the urethral catheter is no longer present. The presence of a urethral catheter may falsely give the impression of a dilated urethra. Other investigations useful in PUV include ultrasound, which can detect PUV both antenatally as well as postnatally.Characteristic bladder features supporting the diagnosis of posterior urethral valves (PUV) include a thickened, heavily trabeculated wall and diverticulum. Key-hole sign has been described in antenatal PUV. A patent urachus may also be visualized. As discussed above, about one-third to one-half of patients will have either unilateral or bilateral vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), which is also detected by the VCUG Based upon the VCUG findings, cystoscopy is performed to confirm the diagnosis and ablate the PUV.

questions.text: Radiological features of skeletal involvement in neurofibromatosis-1 (NF-1) include?
questions.solution: Ans: A D E Ref. Sutton 7th Ed, Sumer Sethi 6th Ed Explanation:The imaging spectrum of NF1 includes • Kyphoscoliosis • Vertebral scalloping: can be associated with dural ectasia or neurofibromas • Dural ectasia • Hypoplastic posterior elements: thinning of the pedicles, transverse processes, and lamina • Transverse process spindling • Enlarged neural foramina • Ribbon rib deformity, rib notching, and dysplasia • Extrinsic pressure may result in deficient bone formation that could be expressed as cortical thinning, erosive defects, sclerosis, and periosteal proliferation • Tibial pseudoarthrosis or, less commonly, ulnar pseudoarthrosis • Bony dysplasias: especially affecting tibia and sphenoid wing • Severe bowing: both lateral and anterior • Multiple non-ossifying fibromas: metaphysis of long bones well-defined, expansile lucent lesions with sclerotic margins • Limb hemihypertrophy

questions.text: Regarding Tc99m, which among the following is/are true?
questions.solution: Ans: A, C, D • It is produced on Mo99 generator on site • It is used as a diagnostic procedure like mekel’s diverticulum , it is not used for radiotherapy. • Half life is 6 hrs

questions.text: Radioactive isotopes of iodine used clinically is/are?
questions.solution: Ans A B C E • I – 123 : half life 13 hrs used for functional scan • I – 124 is used for PET scan • I – 125: half life is 60 days, used for radioiodine assay, brachytherapy • I – 127 is stable isotope • I – 131: half life is 8 days , used to treat well differentiated thyroid cancer

questions.text: Cause(s) of ivory vertebra is/are?
questions.solution: Ans: A, B, D Ivory vertebrae means dense and sclerotic vertebrae. It is seen in pagets disease. Pagets disease also has picture frame vertebrae. Ivory vertebrae is also seen in lymphoma and metastasis

questions.text: Which among the following is/are associated with tell-tale sign?
questions.solution: Ans:A Tell tale triangle sign is a triangular pocket of air found in between bowel loops.

choices.text: White line of Fraenkel appears after Vitamin D treatment

questions.text: Radiological feature(s) of rickets include(s)?
questions.solution: Ans: B D • Widening of epiphysis is a feature of JRA and hemophyllic arthropathy. Rickets shows physeal widening • Rickets show cupping, fraying, splaying of metaphysis • White line of Fraenkel appears after Vitamin D treatment which is a sign of healing of provisional zone of calcification • Sclerotic rim or wimberger ring is seen in scurvy

questions.text: For the diagnosis of neuroendocrine tumours, which among the following is/are used?
questions.solution: Ans: B • Lutetium is strong beta emitter and weak gamma emitter . it is used as targeted radiotherapy • Gallium 68 PET and octreoscan is used for diagnosis of neuroendocrine tumour

questions.text: To detect little amount of pleural effusion radiologically, which among the following can be used?
questions.solution: Ans: D E -Best radiography for pleural effusion: Lateral Decubitus radiograph -Best investigation for pleural effusion: USG - Blunting of Costo-phrenic angle > Earliest finding >1 St finding on chest X-ray PA view >200-300 cc of fluid > Posterior CP angle recess - First place where fluid accumulates - USG findings in Pleural effusion: -Detect as low as 5-10 ml of fluid - Used in USG guided pleural tapping

questions.text: Gated myocardial perfusion scintigraphy uses?
questions.solution: Ans: B C E • Tc RBC is used for ventricular function assessment. It is known as gated MUGA scan. • Tc pyrophosphate is used for the myocardial infarct scintigrahy. This isotope binds to the infarct and the isotope appears hot on the scan

questions.text: Following investigation is-
questions.solution: Ans. C Simple HSG • Done 8-12 days after LMP • IOC for tubal patency MR HSG can look at mullerian abnormalities alsong with patency of tube

questions.text: The following radiological image is showing which of the following disease:
questions.solution: Ans. D Bladder calculus lies above pubic symphysis

questions.text: The following image shows which of the following procedure:
questions.solution: Ans. D Canula put through bile duct and drainage done

questions.text: A patient with suspected esophageal perforation. What is the safest contrast to be used for esophagography?
questions.solution: Ans. A • Safest contrast during thoracic esophageal perforation is IOHEXOL > BARIUM • Safest contrast during abdominal esophageal perforation is GASTROGRAFFIN

questions.text: In the following image of angiography, identify the artery shown:
questions.solution: Ans. B Superior mesenteric artery gives brances on both right and left side. Inferior mesenteric artery gives branches only on left side.

questions.text: A neonate presents with congestive heart failure, on examination enlarging fontanelle, bruit on auscultation, and radiological image (below) found. Most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution: Ans. A The clinical details given above points out to arterio-venous malformation. Site: median prosencephalic vein ie vien of gallen malformation.

questions.text: Bragg’s radiation/peak is produce by:
questions.solution: Ans. B Bragg’s peak occurs when heavy and charged particles are used for radiotheraphy. They deposit all their energy as a peak only at their target.

questions.text: The following image shows sign of which disease:
questions.solution: Ans. A Craniopharyngioma • The tumour is present in supra-sellar region, separate from the pituitary.

questions.text: A 40-years-old bedridden patient presented with sudden breathlessness. An investigation is shown below, what is the diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans. C Saddle shaped embolus present in pulmonary artery.

questions.text: CT scan of thorax. Identify structure:
questions.solution: Ans. D

questions.text: Which of the following is water soluble contrast
questions.solution: Ans: B Most of the iodinated dyes are water soluble. Oil soluble iodinated dye is myodil (not used now). Barium dyes are insoluble in water hence not used in perforation peritonitis.

questions.text: Identify the chest X ray of a patient with low grade fever
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Multiple small millet sized nodular opacities in bilateral lung fileds suggestive of military TB. Similar appearance can be seen in histoplasmosis, varicella, silicosis, sarcoidosis, metastasis, coal worker oneumoconiosis and hemosiderosis

questions.text: A patient presented with history of diplopia and restricted eye movements. A clinical image and a CT image is shown below. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution: Ans: D The above image shows ‘Tear drop sign”.

questions.text: Identify the radiological procedure shown below
questions.solution: Ans: A • Barium enema: large bowel • Enetroclysis is small bowel enema in which dye is inserted through a tube placed in small bowel. Dye doesn’t enter stomach

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the below image
questions.solution: Ans: A Lacunar infarcts are small (<15 mm) infarcts in the distal distribution of deep penetrating vessels (lenticulostriate, thalamoperforating, and pontine perforating arteries, recurrent artery of Heubner). They result from occlusion of one of the small penetrating end arteries at the base of the brain and are due to fibrinoid degeneration. Radiographic features CT In an acute setting, lacunar infarcts appear as ill-defined hypodensities.Chronic lesions appear as hypodense foci (similar to CSF). MRI In an acute setting, the following signal changes are seen: • T1: slightly hypointense • T2/FLAIR: hyperintense • DWI: restricted diffusion • may demonstrate acute lesions not visible on other sequences • T1C+: may enhance if acute (or early subacute) Chronic lesions are isointense to CSF on all sequences but may demonstrate a peripheral T2/FLAIR hyperintense rim of marginal gliosis.
